Carnot Engine Providing Energy to Run an Electric Motor

statement.p: An engine working in a Carnot cycle between two heat baths of temperatures 600\text{ K} and 273\text{ K} runs an electric motor that uses 60\text{ W} of power. If each cycle is completed in 10 seconds, how much heat does the engine absorb from the higher-temperature bath in each cycle?

hint.p: Use W = P\Delta t to find the work the engine should produce.

solution.p:
The efficiency
\eta = \frac{T_H - T_C}{T_H} = \frac{327}{600} = 0.545.
The work output in each cycle is
W = P\Delta t = 60\ \text{W}\times 10\ \text{s} = 600\ \text{J}.
Therefore
Q_{in} = \frac{W}{\eta} = \frac{600\ \text{J}}{0.545} = 1100\ \text{J}.

problem.title: Using a Carnot Engine to Run a Carnot Refrigerator

statement.p: A Carnot cycle working between 100^{\circ}\text{C} and 30^{\circ}\text{C} is used to drive a refrigerator between -10^{\circ}\text{C} and 30^{\circ}\text{C}. (a) How much energy must the Carnot engine produce per second so that the refrigerator is able to discard 10 Joules of energy per second? (b) How much heat does the Carnot engine take in each second from its hot bath source to produce the work required to run the refrigerator at 10\text{ J/s} rate?

hint.p: First find the work required to discard 10 J.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(a) The definition of the coefficient of performance of the refrigerator gives the work required to extract Q_C from the refrigerator.
W = \frac{Q}{\beta}.
The coefficient of performance \beta for a Carnot refrigerator can be computed from the temperatures inside and outside.
\beta = \frac{T_C}{T_H-T_C} = \frac{263.15}{40} = 6.58.
Therefore we need the engine to supply the following energy per second.
W = \frac{Q}{\beta} = \frac{10\ \text{J}}{6.58} = 1.52\ \text{J}.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) Since we need 1.52\text{ J} of energy from the engine we need
Q_{in} \amp = \frac{W}{\eta} = \frac{W T'_H}{T'_H - T'_C} \amp = \frac{1.52\ \text{J} \times 373.15}{ 70} = 8.1\ \text{J}.
Thus, in the end we need to spend 8.1\text{J} of thermal energy from the ultimate source in the engine/refrigerator combined system to take out 10\text{ J} of energy from inside the refrigerator assuming the temperature of the bath at 30^{\circ}\text{C} does not change.

problem.title: Carnot Engine Driving a Carnot Refrigerator

statement.p: The work output of a Carnot engine operating between temperatures T_1 and T_2 with T_1>T_2 is used to drive a refrigerator between temperatures T_3 and T_4 where T_3>T_4. Find the ratio of heat taken from thermal baths T_1 and T_4 in terms of the four temperatures.

hint.p: Work in one cycle of engine will be the work used by the refrigerator.

solution.p:
In this problem, we have a Carnot engine and a Carnot refrigrator. Let us denote the quantities of refrigerator by a prime and those of the engine without a prime. We wish the work produced by the engine to be equal to the work used by the refrigerator.
Q_H - Q_C = Q^\prime_H - Q^\prime_C.
Dividing both sides by $Q_H Q'_C$ gives
\frac{1}{Q^\prime_C} \left(1 - \frac{Q_C}{Q_H}\right) = \frac{1}{Q_H} \left( \frac{Q^\prime_H}{Q^\prime_C} - 1\right).
Carnot cycles have
\frac{Q_H}{Q_C} = \frac{T_1}{T_2}\ \ \textrm{and}\ \ \frac{Q^\prime_H}{Q^\prime_C} = \frac{T_3}{T_4}.
Therefore,
\frac{Q_H}{Q^\prime_C} = \frac{\frac{T_3}{T_4} - 1}{1 - \frac{T_2}{T_1}} = \left( \frac{T_3-T_4}{T_1-T_2}\right)\ \frac{T_1}{T_4}.
